newsitem.title: UK: NWE fuel oil barges end steady after trading highe.
newsitem.headline: NWE fuel oil barges end steady after trading highe.

text.p: European high sulphur fuel oil barges ended steady on Monday after trading higher earlier in the day in what was seen as a player trying to set a higher trend, while cargoes talked firm after Russian material traded strongly on Friday.

After a Rotterdam-based trader initially bought at $85 a tonne fob ARA, or some $1 over Friday's close, high sulphur barges moved down throughout the day to trade at $84.50, $84 and $83.25 or within Friday's early trading range.
Traders said the initial trade was a failed attempt to set a higher trend for the day.
"I think they just wanted to fix a higher price early in the day, but it did not work as all talk turned lower later to about $83.50/$84," one trader said.
Rotterdam bunkers lost early gains with little sign of demand, with 380 CST fuel sold for as low as $85 fob after barge prices sagged, and Hamburg bunkers moved in line with Rotterdam.
Some traders said the low level of enquiries partly explained the afternoon weakness in the barge market.
Low sulphur fuel barges were quiet in a steady market at the $95/$97 mark after a deal on Friday at $97 fob for 1,000 tonnes.

High sulphur was talked steady to a shade firmer after two Russian M-100 cracked cargoes went for $82 cif late on Friday. The first cargo was bought by a U.K.-based refiner and the second by a French refiner.
One percent was also quiet with two sellers at $95 after a deal on Friday at $1 lower, but the few buyers on the market were heard at around $93.
